item.title: John Ganz and Steven Klein: A Serious Man
item.description:
Pontifications

  • From: John Ganz and Steven Klein: A Serious Man

QUOTE

"It is not the duty of intellectuals to be reassuring and edifying, to create a serious world for adult children to wrap themselves up in: they are supposed to be critics not clerics. Their job is to provide tools to weather the sometimes enervating, painful, and confusing path of reflection and thought, not to allow for its easy interruption with images of glory. And their task is certainly not to turn individuals into adulating crowds. In the hands of false prophets, the crowd quickly becomes a mob. "

END QUOTE

Read the whole thing!

item.title: Mike Caulfield on computational propaganda: This is Arendt’s propaganda machine, automated.
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Mike Caulfield on computational propaganda in "Computational Propaganda and Totalitarianism (A Thread)": "This is Arendt’s propaganda machine, automated."
    • Preach it!
    • In a comment, Mike links to Molly K. McKew Russian bots and their American allies gamed social media to put a flawed intelligence document atop the political agenda. That should alarm us. : which has this juicy nugget:

QUOTE

"This bears repeating: Computational propaganda—defined as “the use of information and communication technologies to manipulate perceptions, affect cognition, and influence behavior”—has been used, successfully, to manipulate the perceptions of the American public and the actions of elected officials."

END QUOTE

item.title: Ian Bicking: '(Firefox) Screenshots makes Mozilla part of the web not just a window onto the web'
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Ian Bicking in Improving the web with small, composable tools: "(Firefox) Screenshots makes Mozilla part of the web not just a window onto the web"
    • Amen! Read the whole thing!

item.title: Mike Bostock's observablehq formerly known as d3.express looks great! Much better than d3.js
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Mike Bostock's observablehq formerly known as d3.express looks great! Much better than d3.js or should I say it's natural evolution to make it friendlier and more accessible!
    • d3.express tutorial from April 2017
    • more up to date observable tutorials from December 2017
      • 5 minute introduction
        • which is part of this set of observable tutorials
    • Circles, Spirals and Sunflower tutorial

item.title: Remember when Lightroom was new and fast and it didn't require a $USD5900 machine to run it fast for 'hobbyist' photographers? Neither do I :-)
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Remember when Lightroom was new and fast and it didn't require a $USD5900 Windows machine (source: Paul Stamatiou @Stammy's Building a Lightroom PC) to run it fast for 'hobbyist' photographers? Neither do I :-)
  • Time to switch to Lightroom CC or something much faster on mobile :-)
  • Moral of the story: All software needs to be ruthlessly refactored eventually i.e. we all build big balls of mud :-) or something!
  • By making RAW files too big and not doing any sort of in-camera or send to iOS and Android workflows, digital camera companies aren't doing 'hobbyists' any favours to make our workflow fast, convenient and fun.

item.title: Why don't I attend conferences or listen to podcasts? Answer: too homogeneous and too long
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Why don't I attend conferences or listen to podcasts? Answer: too homogeneous and too long
  • I'd rather talk to people in the lobby of a conference or at a cafe then listen to a talk for 20-60 minutes.
  • I'd rather people summarize their stuff in the 1st 10 slides (or less! I bet most folks talks could be 5 slides and most podcasts could be 10 minutes or less) and talk for 5 or 10 minutes and then do a long Q&A (and put the long form detailed stuff in a wiki page or blog post that they link to in those slides)
  • I'd rather not have more of the same sorts of the same people who are always on the radio and in the books I read and in the media I consume when I can easily find more diverse voices on the internet without going to a conference and without enduring a >30 minute podcast!
  • Having said that conferences with diverse folks and speakers are still appealing and so are short podcasts (although short podcasts seem to be very very scarce!).

item.title: Anybody have a corpus of Software Support questions I can use for sentiment training for Firefox support or do I have to develop my own?
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Anybody have a corpus of Software Support questions I can use for sentiment training for Firefox support or do I have to develop my own?
  • Pretty much resigned to developing my own :-) I have the data and technology just not much time for this "20%" hobbyist project.

item.title: Douglas Hofstadter in the Atlantic: The Shallowness of Google Translate (because computers don't really have any understanding)
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Douglas Hofstadter in the Atlantic: The Shallowness of Google Translate:

QUOTE

When, one day, a translation engine crafts an artistic novel in verse in English, using precise rhyming iambic tetrameter rich in wit, pathos, and sonic verve, then I’ll know it’s time for me to tip my hat and bow out.

END QUOTE

  • Amen! and that day doesn't look like it will happen without a breakthrough. Neural networks and the other brute force techniques won't get us there. Good enough for Go and Chess, not good enough for "C3P0-style" fluency and understanding.
  • I think that breakthrough (quantum computers? ) will come in my lifetime but what do I know :-) ?

item.title: Internet disrupts industry after industry but that industry edifice lasts far longer than technologists think, only to one day collapse far quicker than anyone expected e.g. Nokia, Nortel and Blackberry
item.description:
Pontifications

  • Not sure the following is true especially for domains that can and should be government regulated like transit and health but I can think of 3 examples: N*kia, Bl*ckberry and N*ortel :-) !
    • From stratechery, Amazon Health:

QUOTE

Internet methodically disrupts industry after industry in some sort of chronological order, but rather that the entire edifice lasts far longer than technologists think, only to one day collapse far quicker than anyone expected

END QUOTE

item.title: Amazing orange measles plot using r, ggpplot
item.description:
Pontifications

Amazing orange measles plot using r, ggpplot using a red colour palette (hence the orange) in Some datasets for teaching data science

QUOTE

Contagious disease data for US states

This dataset contains yearly counts for Hepatitis A, measles, mumps, pertussis, polio, rubella, and smallpox for US states. Original data courtesy of Tycho Project. I use it to show ways one can plot more than 2 dimensions.

END QUOTE

library(RColorBrewer)
data("us_contagious_diseases")
the_disease <- "Measles"
us_contagious_diseases %>%
  filter(!state%in%c("Hawaii","Alaska") & disease ==  the_disease) %>%
  mutate(rate = count / population * 10000 * 52 / weeks_reporting) %>%
  mutate(state = reorder(state, rate)) %>%
  ggplot(aes(year, state,  fill = rate)) +
  geom_tile(color = "grey50") +
  scale_x_continuous(expand=c(0,0)) +
  scale_fill_gradientn(colors = brewer.pal(9, "Reds"), trans = "sqrt") +
  geom_vline(xintercept=1963, col = "blue") +
  theme_minimal() +  theme(panel.grid = element_blank()) +
  ggtitle(the_disease) +
  ylab("") +
  xlab("")
  • Much to learn from the above code!
